overview: This unit introduces the problem of personal identity, exploring various perspectives and thought experiments that challenge our understanding of what makes us the same person over time. It contrasts substance and psychological approaches to personal identity, setting the stage for a deeper dive into these theories.

key_points: Personal identity is a philosophical problem concerning what makes a person the same person over time.
There are different approaches to understanding personal identity, including substance-based and psychology-based theories.
Thought experiments and real-life cases like amnesia and split-brain patients challenge our intuitive notions of personal identity.
sections.narrative: The problem of personal identity centers on determining what makes a person the same person over time, despite physical and psychological changes. We start to address the basic question, 'What am I?'  Several views are presented, including that we are collections of cells, brains, or sets of psychological states.  Thought experiments involving scenarios like total recall, where memories can be implanted, or real-life conditions like amnesia, where memories are lost, or the existence of split-brain patients (where the communication between hemispheres of the brain is severed) help to highlight the complexities involved in this philosophical area.

overview: This unit focuses on Locke's theory of personal identity. It looks at his claim that personal identity depends on 'psychology', and not substance.  It covers Locke's arguments against the soul theory, including dreamless sleep and the prince and the cobbler, and introduces Reid's critique of Locke based on transitivity.

key_points: Locke rejects the idea that personal identity depends on having the same soul or the same body.
Locke argues that personal identity is based on continuity of consciousness and memory.
Locke uses thought experiments, like the Prince and the Cobbler, to illustrate his points.
sections.narrative: Locke rejects the soul theory (the idea that personal identity depends on the sameness of a soul) and considers thought experiments and real life cases for support. The thought experiment of the Prince and the Cobbler (switching bodies) and the phenomenon of dreamless sleep both point towards what matters being psychological. To explain the concept of identity, Locke distinguishes between physical particles (continuous space-time), inanimate objects (same particles), and animate objects (same life). Locke's memory link theory: A is the same person as B if and only if B remembers having an experience as A.

quizzes.correct_answer: Consciousness and memory.

sections.narrative: Thomas Reid attacks Locke's positive theory, arguing that it violates our firm notions of transitivity (that is, if A=B and B=C, then A=C). Reid has several arguments for the same soul, different person (sleep, different psychologies), and makes his case with his story of the brave officer and the general that does not remember his childhood whipping. overview: This unit explores the Bundle Theory, an alternative view of personal identity that rejects the existence of a single, enduring self. It introduces Hume's version of this theory, as well as related ideas on what it means to be a good person. The unit includes a look at Buddhist perspectives as well.

key_points: Hume maintains that the self is 'nothing but a bundle or collection of different perceptions'.
There is no single, unified self, only a collection of experiences.
The bundle theory aligns with certain Buddhist philosophies that deny a permanent self.
sections.narrative: The psychological branch is explored with Hume's Bundle Theory.  Hume denies that there is such a thing as the self; instead, there's just a bundle or a collection of different perceptions that are in perpetual flux. According to the bundle theory, the self is the collection of psychological traits. This helps to explain why the self can be moved from soul A to soul B. This view has implications for how we think about ethics.  This thinking is related to certain views about Buddhism, as well, who deny there is a self.

sections.narrative: The course materials touch upon Parfit's Fission Argument for the bundle theory. The materials present this as different from Reid, who would insist that psychology is secondary to the basic fact of identity. However, Parfit embraces the counterintuitive consequences of this stance: if the person in the future will really be me, there is a justification to give one's future self an advantage over other people. Otherwise, what is the justification? The course materials suggest that the shift away from self-centered view is, in effect, a 'philosophy as therapy'.

overview: This unit discusses problems that arise for the bundle theory. These stem from strict identity and from problems of multiplication. Furthermore, it presents the Indivisibility Condition of Souls as a rejoinder.

key_points: Bundle theory does not account for strict identity. A bundle can always be tweaked.
Reid criticizes bundle theory for not being able to secure strict identity across time.
Theorists like Buddha, Hume, and Parfit just accept that strict identity does not exist.
sections.narrative: The course says that, if the bundle theory is correct, then strictly speaking, I'm not the same person I was yesterday. This is because of the course's insistence that there is some sense of 'strict' identity, which is all or nothing. Reid criticized bundle theory for not being able to secure strict identity across time. Also, there is a difficulty when there is a 'multiplication' of bundles; the example given in the course materials is the teletransporter paradox, because technically, there can be multiple copies of my exact bundle! How is it that there is still only ME?
